rules.title: Quoting and Citing Parentheticals
rules.text:
SLR always requires a (quoting . . .) parenthetical when quoted material itself quotes another source. If the author has forgotten to include a quoting parenthetical, you are responsible for adding one yourself and conducting all the sourcepulling, citechecking, and bluebooking required.

“This is a sentence from X that ‘quotes from another source Y.’” X (quoting Y).

SLR never requires a (citing . . .) parenthetical. But authors may elect to do so. Do not delete them.

For quoting and citing parentheticals, you are responsible for citechecking the quoted or cited source just as if the author had cited it directly.

rules.title: Identifying References (Drop Citations)
rules.text:
When a citation is used solely to identify a particular authority—rather than to support a factual or legal proposition—the footnote call number should appear immediately after the source (and after any punctuation mark except for a dash or colon, see BB 1.1(a)), in the text.

Justice Brandeis never knew about Brown v. Board of Education1 or Between the World and Me;2 both were written after he died.

1. 347 U.S. 483 (1954).
2. TA-NEHISI COATES, BETWEEN THE WORLD AND ME (2015).

Note: When a source is introduced in a sentence but also supports its proposition, this rule does not apply. Include only a single footnote with the call number where it would otherwise appear. However, this rule interacts with RB 1.4 if the source supports only part of a sentence. In these situations, leave an [SE:] Comment and a note in the master spreadsheet suggesting a rewrite.

rules.title: Cases Named in Text
rules.text:
If a footnote supports text that names the case cited, the case name need not be repeated in the footnote, so long as the case name used in the text would be sufficient for the type of citation (long or short-form) required in the corresponding footnote. See BB 10.9; see also RB 10.9.

Thus, if a case is named in the text but has not been cited within the preceding five footnotes, the case must either be spelled out (1) in full in the text and omitted from the footnote or (2) in short in the text and in full in the footnote.

rules.title: Footnote Call Number Placement
rules.text:
SLR deviates from BB 1.1 in placing footnote call numbers at the end of a sentence if the source cited supports only part of the sentence.

The police were unable to obtain a warrant, but discovered the evidence in plain view.3

3. See California v. Ciraolo, 476 U.S. 207, 213 (1986) (explaining the plain-view doctrine).

In this example, the citation supports only the second clause of the sentence. Under SLR’s rule, the footnote call number goes at the end of the sentence (after the period) rather than after “plain view.”

A similar rule applies when the source supports only one of multiple independent clauses separated by semicolons (or em dashes). Place the footnote call number at the end of the entire sentence, after the period. But if the sources are in the same clause, the footnote call number is placed at the end of the clause (before the semicolon).

rules.title: Multiple Sources Following Compare and Contrast
rules.text:
When using compare and contrast signals, separate multiple sources with semicolons. Do not use commas to separate them. See BB 1.2; cf. BB 1.3.

Compare Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (1973), with Doe v. Bolton, 410 U.S. 179 (1973); compare Brown v. Bd. of Educ., 347 U.S. 483 (1954), with Plessy v. Ferguson, 163 U.S. 537 (1896).

✶ ✶ ✶

✶ Note that multiple sources following other signals are separated by commas (e.g., See X, Y, and Z). This rule applies only when using compare/contrast signals.

rules.title: When a Source Quotes or Cites Multiple Sources
rules.text:
If an author cites a source that, in turn, quotes or cites multiple other sources, avoid citing through to the underlying sources. Just cite the source that the author cited or quoted.

Quote: The Court noted “that [the death] penalty is an unusually severe and degrading punishment,” Trop v. Dulles, 356 U.S. 86, 99 (1958), but it ultimately upheld the punishment.

Article: The Court noted “that [the death] penalty is an unusually severe and degrading punishment,” but it ultimately upheld the punishment.44

44. Trop v. Dulles, 356 U.S. 86, 99 (1958).

As shown in this example, the author quoted a sentence from Trop v. Dulles that itself quoted the “unusually severe and degrading” language from another source. The author could have cited Trop’s underlying source, but didn’t. That’s fine — and you should not add a citation to the underlying source. Just keep the Trop citation.

rules.title: Preferred Sources and Quoting or Citing Parentheticals
rules.text:
When possible, quote or cite from the source that SLR prefers (as identified in RB 15.5), even when the author has not used SLR’s preferred source.

For example, if an author quotes from THE FEDERALIST NO. 10, and the quote appears in multiple editions, SLR has preferred sources. See, e.g., RB 15.5. If the piece you are editing cites or quotes a nonpreferred edition, find the quote in SLR’s preferred edition and switch to that edition.

If SLR has no preference, however, leave the author’s choice alone.

rules.title: Length of Explanatory Parentheticals
rules.text:
Try to keep explanatory parentheticals short (generally, under fifty words). Explanatory parentheticals usually merely provide an example, explanation, or parenthetical quotation. If a thought is lengthy, consider breaking it out into its own sentence.

Note: Per BB 1.5, a parenthetical phrase that is grammatically part of a sentence (rather than an example, explanation, or quote) is not preceded by an em dash.

✶ ✶ ✶

✶ If an explanatory parenthetical is over fifty words, consider suggesting in an [SE:] Comment that the author shorten it or make it its own sentence.

rules.title: Grammar of Explanatory Parentheticals
rules.text:
Explanatory parentheticals must start with a present participle, a quoted sentence, or a short quotation: “(arguing that . . .)”, “(“They started on a campaign of harassment.”)”, or “(“start[ing] on a campaign of harassment” [emphasis added])”. See BB 1.5.

They should never start with a capital letter (unless the first word is a proper noun), a direct quote that is a full sentence (i.e., beginning with a capital letter and ending with a period), or a parenthetical letter. They should also never start with a present participle that doesn’t agree with the subject of the main sentence, a main verb, or an article (a, an, the).

If it’s unclear whether a present participle agrees with the subject, you have a couple options. Often, you can add a few words to clarify the participle’s meaning. Alternatively, consider leaving an [SE:] Comment suggesting a rewrite. (If you do leave a comment, be sure to also note the issue in the master spreadsheet.)

rules.title: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization
rules.text:
When indicating altered capitalization or added emphasis in a quote, use a single parenthetical that covers both. Specifically, use “(alteration in original)” or “(emphasis added)”, not “(capitalization altered)” or “(alteration and emphasis in original)”. See BB 5.2.

SLR deviates from BB 5.2 in that if both capitalization and emphasis have been altered in a quote, you should still just write “(alteration in original)” or “(emphasis added)”. Do not use “(alteration and emphasis added)” or “(alteration and emphasis in original)”.

SLR is more concerned with substance than form, so don’t fret if an author doesn’t note an added emphasis or altered capitalization. Just leave it be.

SLR is less concerned with Bluebook perfection than it is with content accuracy and consistency. If an author adds emphasis in a quote without noting it, or if an author alters capitalization in a quote, do not bother adding a parenthetical. It is not our job to edit on a micro-level — or to “Bluebook” a piece — with such intensity. That said, if something in the quote really seems off, leave an [SE:] Comment and a note in the master spreadsheet.

rules.title: Explanatory Parentheticals and In
rules.text:
Contrary to BB 1.5(b), BB 1.6(a)(i), and the Rand example in footnote 5 of BB 15.10.1, SLR convention is to place explanatory parentheticals after the collection information (rather than after the “in” phrase introducing the collection). For example:

Jane Doe, Toward a Theory, in GREAT PAPERS 3, 4 (2024) (arguing that . . .).

The Bluebook suggests that the parenthetical explanation belong after “Jane Doe, Toward a Theory,”, before the “in” phrase. But SLR instead places it at the end, as in the above example. If you see an “in”-introductory parenthetical in a citation, shift it to the end.

Note: There is an exception for cases in which the explanatory parenthetical applies to the larger work (rather than to the source within the larger work). For example:

Jane Doe, Toward a Theory, in GREAT PAPERS 3 (John Smith ed., 2024) (collection of essays analyzing . . .).

Here, the explanatory parenthetical applies to Great Papers (the larger work) as a whole, so it belongs before the “in” phrase. But if it applies to the smaller work (Jane Doe’s essay), it belongs at the end of the cite. When in doubt about where the explanatory parenthetical belongs in an “in” citation, just leave an [SE:] Comment. The SE will figure it out.

rules.title: Bolded Type
rules.text:
SLR uses bold text only in Extraordinary Circumstances. Specifically, a Stanford Law Review print piece may use bold in the rare case that the author’s argument explicitly centers around an emphasized word (e.g., a piece about “fair” vs. “free” trade). Bold type is sometimes used for Article titles in citations; you should follow the author’s lead on whether to apply that rule. See BB 16.7.3.

Do not add bold for emphasis in any other circumstances, and remove it if authors add it.

rules.title: Pincites
rules.text:
Always include a pincite when citing a case, statute, book, or other nonperiodical source, even if citing the source as a whole. Do not, however, include pincites when citing cases in textual sentences. See BB 3.2; BB 10.9.

That is, if you write, “In Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (1973), the Court . . .”, don’t include a pincite after 113.

rules.title: Hereinafter
rules.text:
Use hereinafter sparingly. Unlike with supra, which should be used for all subsequent references to a source (other than with cases, statutes, etc.), hereinafter should only be used when a supra would be confusing. Hereinafter is most common for sources with very long titles and similar beginnings or multiple sources by the same author in the same year.

Even if the Bluebook would allow a hereinafter, default to using supra for cases in which the potential confusion is minimal.

See BB 4.2.

rules.title: Block Quotes
rules.text: SLR follows BB 5.1 in using block quotes for quotations of fifty or more words. As BB 5.1(a) suggests, it is often permissible to avoid a block quote by simply not quoting extraneous language (e.g., starting and ending a quote in the middle of a sentence), and you should do so when possible. But do not rewrite quotes just to avoid block quoting, and do not try to sneak in a forty-nine-word quotation to avoid a block quote when a longer quote would provide essential context.

rules.title: Omissions from Quotations
rules.text:
Use an ellipsis ( . . . ) to indicate the omission of one or more words from the middle of a quoted sentence. Do not use an ellipsis at the beginning of a quotation (even if the beginning of the sentence is omitted) or at the end of a quotation (even if the end of the sentence is omitted) unless what follows in the sentence is also omitted. If one or more full sentences are omitted from the quotation, use an ellipsis that includes end punctuation (e.g., “. . . .”). Leave a space before and after each period in the ellipsis. Do not omit punctuation before or after the ellipsis unless it is a comma that serves only to indicate a series of items.

See BB 5.3–5.4.

rules.title: Alterations to Quotations
rules.text:
Use brackets to indicate any alterations to the text of a quotation, including altered capitalization, added or changed emphasis, or added footnote call numbers. See RB 1.13; BB 5.2.

Use “[sic]” to indicate any obvious errors or misprints in the original quotation that you cannot correct (but for minor errors, consider paraphrasing instead). Do not use “[sic]” to indicate an alternate but still correct spelling (e.g., alternate spelling of a word ending in “-ize” or “-yze”). See RB 24.1.

rules.title: Textual Citations Within Quotations
rules.text:
In general, citations within quotations should be omitted unless particularly relevant.

Original source: The Court specified “with all deliberate speed,” Brown II, 75 S. Ct. at 757, but that phrase is not a model of clarity.

Article: As one commentator noted, “The Court specified ‘with all deliberate speed,’ but that phrase is not a model of clarity.”373

373. Collin Fredricks & Catherina Y. Xu, One Thousand and One Galley Nights, 76 STAN. L. REV. 1789, 1895 (2023) (citation omitted) (quoting Brown v. Bd. of Educ. (Brown II), 349 U.S. 294, 301 (1955)).

If the quoted citation is particularly relevant and must be retained, it should appear as it does in the quoted source—including, unfortunately, any Bluebooking errors.

rules.title: Introducing Acronyms and Initialisms
rules.text:
If an acronym or initialism is not widely known, write out its full name the first time it is used, followed immediately by the acronym or initialism in parentheses.

Right: the Department of Energy (DOE)
Wrong: the Department of Energy (DOE Department)
Wrong: the Department of Energy

It is also often helpful to remind the reader of an acronym or initialism’s meaning if it hasn’t appeared for a while. In those cases, either reintroduce it parenthetically or note in the text that it refers to the same thing as an earlier acronym or initialism.

See BB 6.1(c).

rules.title: Headings, Subheadings, and Text
rules.text:
SLR’s authors use title-style capitalization for headings and subheadings (meaning that, as stated above, all words are capitalized except articles, conjunctions, and prepositions of four or fewer letters). SLR departs from BB 8 in also using title-style capitalization for text (including the title of the piece and author’s name) that appears on the first page of the piece. Do not “downstyle” any text (e.g., the author’s title or position) that appears on the first page.

See BB 8; BB 9.

rules.title: Citechecking Cases
rules.text:
For each case a piece cites, ensure that the case is still good law. If any negative treatment has since occurred (e.g., overruled, abrogated, superseded), add a parenthetical explaining that. Additionally, verify that the case name and reporter information are accurate. Don’t assume that an author’s citations to commonly cited cases (e.g., Roe v. Wade) are correct; always cross-check.

If a case has been granted cert and is pending before SCOTUS, note in a parenthetical that cert is pending; if a case is pending before a federal en banc panel, note that; etc.

If you aren’t sure whether to flag a case, leave an [SE:] Comment for your SE.

See BB 10.7.1; BB 10.7.2.

rules.title: Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases
rules.text:
Always use free sources in lieu of database citation strings for cases when possible. For example, a citation to the Supreme Court’s 2021 OSHA vaccine mandate decision should be: Nat’l Fed’n of Indep. Bus. v. Dep’t of Labor, Occupational Safety & Health Admin., No. 21A244, 595 U.S. ___ (Jan. 13, 2022) (per curiam), https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/21pdf/21a244_hgci.pdf.

Conversely, avoid Westlaw citations if a case is available for free elsewhere. If a case is available on SCOTUSblog, or from a news organization, link to that version rather than a Westlaw version (so long as the version is clearly the same document). Do not use “2022 WL . . .” if a case was decided in 2022. Instead, find an official version (see RB 11.1). For newly decided cases, this can be an official PDF if one is available (as in the vaccine mandate case above) or the website of a credible news outlet or law professor. Avoid SSRN, though, unless no other source is available.

Similarly, avoid “slip op.” or “manuscript” parentheticals (see BB 10.8.1(a)) if an alternate source is available. Those signals are intended to indicate that a source is temporarily unavailable in an official reporter, but if a free source is available, the more useful parenthetical is a URL.

rules.title: Preferred Versions of Common Works and Special Citation Forms
rules.section: BOOKS, REPORTS, AND OTHER NONPERIODIC MATERIALS
rules.text:
Below are special rules SLR follows for certain commonly cited works. They are often similar to Bluebook rules but with a twist or additional nuance (or they are otherwise easily overlooked by editors). If a piece you are editing cites one of these works or types of sources, be sure to follow these rules.
• American Law Reports: When citing a proposition supported by multiple ALR entries, list multiple ALR entries in the same parenthetical with semicolons between them, even if published decades apart. (This is a departure from the Bluebook’s normal rule for related authorities, where sources are separated by semicolons only if they were published within twenty years.)
• Black’s Law Dictionary: Don’t include the edition number; instead, include the year that the edition was published in the parenthetical.
• Federalist papers: SLR’s official version is compiled in Ralph Ketcham’s The Anti-Federalist Papers and the Constitutional Convention Debates (1986). Cite that version for any references to Federalist essays (e.g., THE FEDERALIST NO. 10). But if an author includes a pinpoint cite, use the page number from the relevant Federalist essay as printed in Ketcham’s volume (even if the essay numbering is different).
• Foreign Affairs Federalist / Pacificus-Helvidius debates: SLR’s official version is compiled in JAMES MADISON & ALEXANDER HAMILTON, THE PACIFICUS-HELVIDIUS DEBATES OF 1793–1794 (Morton J. Frisch ed., 2007).
• The Federalist (anti-federalist): For the anti-federalist Federal Farmer letters, SLR’s official version is compiled in ESSAYS OF THE CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION (Paul Leicester Ford ed., 1892). We often cite these letters as Federal Farmer letters, despite their name.
• U.N. Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS): SLR’s official source is the United Nations website, which contains the final official version of the convention in PDF form. If in doubt about which version of a work to use, leave an [SE:] Comment. See BB 15.7; BB 21.5.

When citing a work contained in a larger collection (e.g., an essay or excerpt in a book-length collection or textbook), SLR’s preference is to cite the smaller work and then the larger work. But if the author cites to the larger work as a whole, that’s fine.

For example:

Right: Jane Doe, Essay Title, in BOOK TITLE 1, 4 (John Doe ed., 2024).

OK: BOOK TITLE 1, 4 (John Doe ed., 2024).

rules.title: Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals and Magazines
rules.text: When citing to a nonconsecutively paginated journal, magazine, or newspaper (as opposed to consecutively paginated law reviews), do not list the volume number if one exists. Instead, list the date followed by the publication name, as with newspaper citations. For example, the Stanford Magazine is a quarterly alumni magazine with nonconsecutive pagination, and you should not include volume/issue numbers in its citations; just treat it like a newspaper. See BB 16.6(d); BB 16.3.5.

rules.title: Open-Access Journals and Certain Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals
rules.text:
Some law journals are “open access” and have electronic articles that are assigned an article number (e.g., 2022 U. CHI. L. REV. ONLINE 1) instead of a page number. Others are nonconsecutively paginated but have PDF page numbers that look like consecutively paginated pages. For any of those, you should use the article number (or first page number) in the citation but also include a URL (or a perma link if needed) at the end of the citation. The University of Chicago Law Review Online is one example; the Harvard National Security Journal is another (its pages look like 1–30 but that’s only within each article’s individual PDF). Other examples include University of Pennsylvania Law Review Online, California Law Review Online, etc.

If in doubt, leave an [SE:] Comment.

See BB 16.8; BB 16.6(d).

rules.title: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles
rules.text:
For newspapers or magazines that have both a print and an online version, cite the version that the author actually used. If an author cites the online version but your sourcepull leads you to the print version, you do not need to change the citation to print; you can just cite the online version (though you may wish to leave an [SE:] Comment noting the existence of a print version). Likewise, if an author cites a print version but you find only the online version, just cite the print version as if you had seen it in print.

See BB 16.6(e).

rules.title: Special Reports in Newspapers
rules.text:
If a citation is to a special report or series in a newspaper (e.g., the New York Times’s “Reckoning” series about Harvey Weinstein, or the Washington Post’s “Opioids” series), include the series name in the citation (in italics, after the newspaper name). For example:

Alan Schwarz, The Talented Mr. Strasburg, N.Y. TIMES (The Reckoning), Sept. 5, 2023, https://perma.cc/XXXX-YYYY.

See BB 16.6.4(a).

rules.title: Citing Abstracts
rules.text:
If an author cites an abstract (for example, an abstract on SSRN or on the AEA website for an economics article), try to find the underlying paper and cite that instead. If you cannot find a non-abstract source, cite the abstract the same way you would a full article, but add “(abstract)” at the end of the parenthetical. For example: “[article info], (Aug. 2023) (abstract).”

See BB 16.7.3.

rules.title: Checking for Special Designations
rules.text:
Always double-check whether any component of the volume, issue, or date needs to be included for a periodical citation. For example, if a piece is in a supplement, you may need to add a “Supp.” designation. Or if a periodical is organized by season rather than month, you may need to add that (e.g., “Fall 2023”). If an issue is a special symposium issue, you may need to add that (e.g., “Symposium Issue”). Authors often leave out those designations, so you should keep an eye out for them.

See BB 16.4; BB 16.5.

rules.title: SSRN Publications
rules.text:
If an author cites a publication that is on SSRN, check whether it has been published elsewhere. If it has, cite to the published version instead. If it has not, include a parenthetical at the end of the citation indicating “manuscript at X”, where X is the page on the PDF that the author is citing (or, if no pincite, the total number of pages preceded by “at”). Add a date if available.

For example: “[author info], (Mar. 2022) (manuscript at 15, SSRN), http://ssrn.com/abstract=1234567.” Or if a pincite is given: “at 15”.

See BB 17.1.1.

rules.title: Avoiding Repetitious Author Names or Page Titles
rules.text:
If citing a web page or report where the page title repeats the author’s name or the organization name (e.g., an “about” page listing a person’s bio information or a PDF report listing an organization as the author and again in the title), you can shorten the title of the source by omitting the repetitious part.

For example, if the citation is to an About Us page for an organization, you might use just the organization name as the main page title if that seems more logical and easier to read. Or if a report’s title repeats the organization’s name, you might shorten the title to exclude the repetition. Always ensure that the shortened title still clearly identifies the source.

If unsure whether to shorten a title, you can leave an [SE:] Comment for guidance.

rules.title: Omitting Words in Main Page Titles
rules.text:
For web page titles that include generic terms like “Home” or the site’s name as part of the main page title, you may omit those if they are not needed for clarity. For example, if a homepage title is “XYZ Organization – Home”, you can just use “XYZ Organization” as the title in the citation.

However, be careful not to remove any unique or necessary part of the title. Only omit parts that are clearly extraneous.

See BB 18.2.3.

rules.title: Dates and Times
rules.text:
Include a timestamp in the date parenthetical of an internet source only if the source itself is updated multiple times a day and listing a time is necessary to identify the version referenced. Otherwise, just include the date. If a source shows a time but the content is not rapidly updated, you can usually omit the time from the citation.

If including a time, use the time zone given or convert to a standard time zone (like ET) if needed, and express it in a consistent format (e.g., “Sept. 5, 2023, 9:30 PM ET”).

See BB 18.2.2(a).

rules.title: Parallel Citations to Internet Sources
rules.text:
If a source is available in multiple formats (e.g., an online article with an accompanying PDF), you generally do not need to provide parallel citations or links to both versions. Cite the version the author used or that is easier for readers to access. If the versions are identical in content, one citation is sufficient.

However, if the different formats contain different information or if it's important to note the existence of another format (such as an archived PDF version), you can include a parenthetical or explanatory phrase.

See BB 18.2.2; BB 18.7.2.

rules.title: Location Parentheticals for Websites
rules.text:
If an online source is part of a website that has sections or a hierarchy, you can include that information parenthetically to clarify where on the site the content is located. For example, a press release might be under a “News” section; you could cite it as: [Title], [Site Name] (Nov. 1, 2023) (press release).

Only add such parentheticals if they help clarify the nature or context of the source.

See BB 18.7.3.

rules.title: Miscellaneous Documents in PDF Form
rules.text:
For miscellaneous PDF documents that are not formally published elsewhere (e.g., an unofficial PDF report or a scanned letter), treat them as internet sources. Provide a descriptive title if needed and the URL. If they have an author and date, include those as you would for an internet source.

For example, a scanned letter titled “Letter from X to Y” (Oct. 3, 2020), could be cited with that title, date, and a URL to the PDF.

Ensure that the citation makes clear what the document is, especially if it's not obvious from the title.

See BB 18.1; BB 17.1.3.

rules.title: Dates for Online PDFs
rules.text:
When citing an online PDF, use the date on the document itself (if available) rather than the date of download or the date the website lists it (unless the latter is the only date available). For example, if a PDF report is dated June 2022 but the site says “posted Aug. 2022”, use June 2022 in the citation.

If a document is undated, use the date the content was last modified or accessed, as per Bluebook rules, and indicate accordingly (e.g., “last modified Mar. 3, 2023” or “accessed Mar. 3, 2023”).

See BB 18.2.2(b).

rules.title: Names in Treaty Titles
rules.text:
Where the title of a treaty includes the names of the parties to the treaty, omit that portion from the title, unless doing so would shorten the treaty name to “Treaty” or otherwise render it too generic. Essentially, focus on the substantive part of the treaty’s title rather than the listing of parties in the title.

For example, if a treaty is titled “Treaty between the Government of X and the Government of Y on Cooperation in Z”, you can shorten it to “Treaty on Cooperation in Z”.

See BB 21.4.5.

rules.title: Spelling
rules.text:
If an alternate but still correct spelling of a word appears in a piece (e.g., “advisor” vs. “adviser”), default to the spelling listed in Merriam-Webster unless there’s a good reason to retain the alternate spelling. However, be cautious when it comes to proper nouns or titles where the spelling is part of an official name.

In general, do not Americanize or Britishize the spelling of quotations—keep them as in the original.

See CMOS 7.1; CMOS 7.2.

rules.title: Plurals
rules.text:
For words that have two plural forms (e.g., “appendixes” vs. “appendices”), use the form listed as the primary variant in Merriam-Webster. If both forms are listed equally, use one consistently throughout the piece.

For words ending in “-us” that have a plural “-i” (like “fungus” vs. “fungi”), use the English plural “-uses” unless the context demands the Latin form.

See CMOS 7.6.

rules.title: Hyphenation
rules.text:
Follow Merriam-Webster for whether a compound is hyphenated, one word, or two words. If Merriam-Webster lists multiple forms (hyphenated vs. closed), use the first-listed form.

However, avoid unnecessary hyphenation in adverbial phrases (for example, do not hyphenate “widely used” as it is clear without a hyphen).

See CMOS 7.89 (guidelines on hyphenation).

rules.title: Quotation Marks and Apostrophes
rules.text:
Use smart quotes (curly quotes) for quotations and apostrophes, not straight quotes or primes. Ensure that any quotation marks or apostrophes in the text appear as proper typographic marks (e.g., “ ” and ‘ ’, not " " or ' '). This often requires checking for instances where a word like “husky’s” might mistakenly use a straight apostrophe instead of a curly one.

Additionally, be mindful of the distinction between an apostrophe and a single opening quote — these can look similar but face different directions in typography.

See CMOS 13.1–13.7.

rules.title: Commas
rules.text:
Use the serial comma (Oxford comma) in lists of three or more items. Additionally, ensure that comma usage follows standard grammar rules (e.g., use a comma before a conjunction in a compound sentence, after introductory phrases, etc.).

Do not use a comma between a subject and verb or between a verb and object unnecessarily. For instance, avoid “The result, was surprising.”

If an author has a stylistic comma (e.g., in a certain phrasing for effect), usually leave it unless it creates confusion or is grammatically incorrect.

See CMOS 6.16–6.21.

rules.title: Hyphens and Dashes
rules.text:
Use hyphens (-) for hyphenating words (e.g., “well-known”). Use en dashes (–) for ranges (e.g., “2019–2020”) and relationships (e.g., “New York–London flight”). Use em dashes (—) for breaks in thought or parenthetical statements—like this.

Make sure not to confuse hyphens with en dashes in number ranges (the latter should be longer). Also, do not put spaces around em dashes.

See CMOS 6.75–6.89.

rules.title: The One-Space Rule
rules.text:
Use only one space after a period (or other terminal punctuation) at the end of a sentence. Do not use two spaces, even if the author does; this should be standardized to one space throughout the piece.

The same rule applies to colons — use one space after a colon (unless in a citation or ratio, where formatting rules may differ).

This is a global find-and-replace job, but be careful not to alter intentional spacing in indented text or fixed-width formats.

See CMOS 6.7.

rules.title: Nonbreaking Spaces
rules.text:
Insert a nonbreaking space (Option+Space on a Mac; Ctrl+Shift+Space on a PC) between a symbol and its corresponding numeral. This is done so that a line break will not separate, for instance, “§ 1983” into the section symbol on one line and the number on the next, or “$ 50” from the number.

Also consider using nonbreaking spaces in other contexts, such as between “U.S.” and “§” or between an initial and a last name (if an initial is used).

Nonbreaking hyphens can also be used in citation spans (to avoid breaks in “2015–2017” for instance).

This is more of a technical typesetting rule; implement it where possible, but it may not always be visible in word processors.

See CMOS 6.36.

rules.title: Dates and Date Ranges
rules.text:
Retain all digits when giving a range of years (for example, “1993–1998,” not “1993–98”).

When referring to decades, do not insert an apostrophe (for example, “1780s,” not “1780’s”). Additionally, if abbreviating a decade, use an apostrophe to indicate omitted numerals (e.g., the ’80s for 1980s).

Spell out months in textual discussions. In citations, follow Bluebook rules (which usually abbreviate longer month names).

See CMOS 9.3; BB 12.1.

rules.text:

Some styles differ on this; SLR follows the Chicago Manual here.

rules.title: Doctrine of Patently Asinine Results
rules.text:
Be on the lookout for instances where blind application of a rule yields a patently asinine result. The “Doctrine of Patently Asinine Results” is an SLR maxim that allows deviation from any rule when following the rule would lead to a clearly absurd outcome. In other words, use common sense: if adhering strictly to a rule makes a sentence or citation look ridiculous or confusing, find a sensible alternative.

Always consult with your SE if you think a situation merits invoking this doctrine; it’s better not to unilaterally decide something is an exception without confirmation.

This doctrine is more of a guiding principle than a formal rule—an editor’s intuition to maintain readability and clarity above strict conformity when necessary.
